Destin: in your comparison of the revolver and the pistol, you indicate that the pistol is more efficient at directing the energy of the expanding gases to the bullet as it loses less from the "jump gap" where the bullet leaves the cylinder and jumps to the barrel. While I agree that this DOES in fact happen- obviously we see it occur, what I was surprised to hear was you essentially discount the revolver as a less efficient device. You did not account for the tremendous loss of potential bullet energy that occurs in the pistol due to using expanding gases to drive the action of the shell ejection and reload.

The only way to effectively compare energies inefficiencies is to run controlled production ammunition through identical barrel lengths (one revolver, one pistol) and determine impact energies.

BTW: what calibers were the handguns? The pistol appeared to be 9mm Parabellum, but I could not decide on the revolver...38? Very cool way to spend some time!!

Another thing I noticed, which you didn't mention, is that you can actually see the compression of water in action. If you look at the 1911 high speed clip, the glass is fractured, but not broken, when the bullet passes through it. It isn't until the shockwave reaches it that it finally breaks. Water isn't incompressible (really it's just almost impossible- 200 kPa to reduce volume by 1%). If it was, aquatic sound would go faster than light, and the glass would shatter right as the bullet hit.

You should try shooting a Nagant revolver underwater. It has a very interesting design unique to revolvers. The cartridge  Nagant is designed to that the case completely hides the bullet inside. And when the shot is fired the drum moves forward and presses the cartridge which protrudes slightly from the drum inside the barrel. Then the powder explodes expanding the cartridge case and thus sealing it tight to the barrel and the bullet goes off in as tight a system as possible. Check it.

A horizontal toroidal vortex is what sailplane pilots call a thermal but it is not just a rising bubble of air as is often taught in flight schools. That is why sailplanes (and soaring birds) fly in circles hunting for the area of maximum lift just on the inside of the (ahem) bagel of air where the air is rising and rolling over the top and then down again.

Gases can expand and compress, liquids not so much.  

Firearms are designed to handle the pressures created by the cartridges they are chambered for, and a little extra for safety.  Firing a gun under water, the gasses are surrounded by a non-compressible aqueous environment, so they, themselves, retain a higher pressure level longer and usually increase max-pressure reached.

This can severely compromise the strength of components or destroy them altogether.  Definitely don't try at home.

The shockwave formed around a supersonic bullet is conical and its angle from the axis of motion is directly proportional to the Mach number at which the bullet travels. Notice, Mach number will vary with different weather conditions for the same airspeed.

The toroidal vortex can be observed with anything that produces a coherent column of gas moving in a specific direction, most notably - a nuclear blast.

That's only if the weapon is fired outside of the water--the surface tension of the water at ballistic velocities is going to be like hitting concrete. Firing a weapon underwater can still be effective, depending on the gun. There are a number of purpose-built underwater rifles and machine guns built by various militaries for this exact reason.

It should also be noted that water basically stops any kind of bullet, from a .22LR all the way up to a .50BMG. A foot or two of water is all it takes for the bullet to break up, slow down, and become non-lethal.

It isn't actually an air space contained within the shell casing. Oxygen is part of the molecule. In other words, it has its own oxidizer. Both the primer and the powder have their own oxidizer. The primer is set off by the pressure of the firing pin whose heat and pressure then sets off the powder by releasing oxygen for it to burn.

The conclusion that the 'extra' gasses escaping to the side of the revolver makes it less efficient in generating velocity compared to a semi auto is flawed. The Nagant 1895 was designed by Mosin and used by the Russian military. It stopped production after WWII. It's a good pistol, for what it is. It was designed in 1895 when revolver tech was in it's infancy. The fact that no other revolver ever followed the gas seal design shows that the velocity loss from an open cylinder is not a real issue, at least not enough to justify the extra complexity. Aresenal rebuilt Nagants are readily available, but it's really just a collector piece now.

The issue with the Nagant revolver is the fact that the reloading was very slow and used a unique ammo. The gas seal cylinder, because of the complexity of the indexing and forward motion to seal the chamber, made the double action trigger pull about 25lbs, that's about 8 times what similar pistols  had. But that didn't stop it from being produced in the millions. The Nagant is the only revolver that can b e silenced. You can buy one today for about a hundred bucks.

Wrong... Gas operated and blow back systems are in no way similar. The energy used to reload semi-auto pistols, except the Jericho (Desert Eagle), is the recoil energy pushing backwards, which is 100% wasted in revolvers. Even in gas operated weapons the bullet is well down range before any internal parts begin to move, not effecting muzzle energy.

While it might seem that revolvers are less efficient because of the expanded gasses leaking, keep in mind that semi-automatics use a "blow back" method that will use a significant amount of gas to reload the gun, while in revolvers, the energy taken to reload comes along with pulling the trigger.

People avoid getting guns wet for several reasons. A couple notable reasons are that many guns will malfunction and become damaged and/or damage the user if fired while full of water, though this is not true for all models, and another notable reason is that guns with metal parts are susceptible to corrosion and the corrosive properties of water. In order to prevent oxidation of this type, guns are typically kept dry, and many surfaces (particularly contact surfaces) are oiled regularly.

@silver760 The case walls are tapered on a 9mm,as soon as the slide extracts the case the seal is broken,long after the bullet has left the barrel.

With the semi pistol the out gassing you saw after the hammer fell,is not gasses escaping around the primer.When the cartridge fires a small amount of air is displaced,along with a small amount of gas as the cartridge case expands to create a seal in the chamber behind the bullet.A fraction of a second after the case expands to seal the chamber the barrel and slide travel rearwards.when the barrel stops it unlocks the slide,then the slide will start to extract the case.

In the movie he used a hand dryer to dry the bullets out, in reality this wouldn't do anything. This is because of how tightly the components are, using a hand dryer, even if it got hot enough would only create stern in the casing. So no in reality this wouldn't fix a bullet that was exposed to liquids for that time period. In fact, placing unwanted or unusable ammo into a bucket of water for a few minutes makes them inert and safe enough to throw in the trash. This means "time to buy more ammo"

The main factors at play when a firearm, lets say pistol for the "shoot em up" movie. The factor for the pistol to fire is the duration in the water. So in the movie the bullets were wet for a while. Most bullets have a great seat in the casing, which is what generates the pressure for firing it. The fictional side is the duration the bullets was exposed around the primer cap. Once water enters around the primer cap and saturates the cap and gun powder round is useless.

The when the pistol fires, a good deal of its energy is used to push back the slide, which also has resistance from a large spring inside the gun, to cycle the next round into the chamber. 

I would think that this action would be equal or greater than the force lost in the revolver due to escaping gasses.

The initial wave out the bore is the precursor wave. The water at rest in the bore in FRONT of the projectile is compressed & pushed out in front of the bullet and cavitation occurs. The the H20 and gases are pressed and conform to the round shape of(Walls?) the bore diameter. Then the bullet & bullet wake from spinning bullet & the resultant toro effect. Gases burn & expand and displace atmosphere around them. At the end you see them collapse back in as pressure goes back down to equalize My 2c

Really liked the music. As long as the water pressure is EQUAL within the firearm, and as long as the bullet is sealed in the case mouth w/ air in the cartridge and a good primer most HANDGUNS won't have a problem. Doesn't matter how much water or how deep IN the water. LONG barrels and SMALL bores will have a longer, higher sustained  pressure curve and can burst - just FYI

Bubble in the rear is most likely the remaining air in the firing pin channel being forced out by the movement of the firing pin. Since the smaller diameter portion of the pin is "leaving" the channel, and the larger diameter (sticking out the back that the hammer hits) is "entering" the channel, a greater net volume of that space would be taken up. Water pressure would force the air out.

@destinws2 Something interesting that you didn't mention: The Ruger's slide didn't cycle completely (and lock on empty) when you shot it underwater. If the magazine had bullets in it, it most likely wouldn't have chambered a new round, requiring you to rack the slide between shots. I've seen other pistols (such as Glocks) cycle underwater just fine though. This probably depend on a lot of factors though (cartridge strength, slide weight, spring tension, etc). Also, glad your pistol didn't KB! :)

@destinws2 I understood about half of the words in this response.

@Qackool the primer is an explosive. It doesn't require O2. The powder burns O2 but it is already in the powder in the form of a solid oxidizer. When the primer detonates it ignites the entire cartridge of powder almost at once reacting the oxidizer with the fuel part of the gunpowder burning the powder and increasing pressure forcing the bullet down the barrel. If gunpowder did not work this way there wouldn't be enough O2 in gas form in the catridge or barrel to create enough energy to fire.

I'm not really surprised that the auto uses the gas better, because, obviously, there is nowhere for the gas to exit but the barrel, as opposed to the gap between the cylinder and the barrel on the revolver.
